transcripts.text: Now, note, this was before the Capitol was stormed, but I think it's important to emphasize that this was the conversation before the Capitol was stormed by one of the more, as they would call her, more reasonable Republicans who comes from the Maverick family.  I'm talking about Meghan McCain, who is back at The View.  And full disclosure, I know this woman.  I know her from cable newsrooms.  Generally speaking, and I'm saying this intentionally because I do think that this is where people get lost.  She reaches across party aisle.  I mean, on the show, clearly, there's some drama happening there.  But off the show, she talks to everybody.  She quotes Democrats.  You're in the newsroom with her.  Her mother, I think, is a little bit more progressive than we all know.  But there's a danger in that.  And what I'm going to show you right now is, I think, highlights this beyond.  So let's play that clip of Meghan McCain with Senator-elect Raphael Warnock.
I agree and join Joe Manchin and agree that you are not for that.

My job is to take the concerns that are being raised by my constituents.  And what I'm telling you is that they're asking about their health care.  They're asking about whether or not they can earn a livable wage for working hard every day.  And they're wondering when in the world are they going to get relief after waiting for it for months.  And right now, what is the Senate doing?  They're engaged in a shameless exercise of privilege and power.  challenging the basic norms of our government.  The people of Georgia rose up and rebuked that kind of policy last night, and I intend to represent their interests in the U.S.  Senate to make sure they have health care, to make sure that they enjoy livable wage, and that their voice can be heard in their democracy.
I'm just asking you a direct question.
Well, I'm just going to, actually, I'm actually going to end this.  Hey, listen, we're going to say thanks to the Senator-elect, Reverend Raphael Warnock, and we will be right back.
Thank you for coming back, sir.  What was she saying, though?  What was the direct question she thought he was avoiding?
She said, Senator, I do believe that average Americans care about packing the courts.  I just want to know if you would agree or join Joe Manchin and agree that you are not for that.

Here's what's so problematic about that statement.  We live in a nation that is civically illiterate.  So what percentage of voters, what percentage of adults, what percentage of anyone who can read and write.  know how many people are on the Supreme Court?  Or know anything about our- You know that the Supreme Court exists.  So that is, she could have framed that differently.  She could have said, if she were operating in good faith, she could have said something like, Do you think it is appropriate for a new majority to expand the Supreme Court to protect their own interests at the expense of the greater good?  Now, I wouldn't agree with that, but that's a little more honest, right?  But we've done it before.  There's nothing that says we can't.  We can do it in the right way, or we could do it in a shabby way.  We could actually expand the size of the Supreme Court to have more diverse and highly competent justices on the Supreme Court.  Even irrespective of their political ideology, they're very competent and smart people who do not share my political philosophy.  I do not believe those people are idiots.  I believe they're wrong.  Right.  There's a difference.  So what he has done and some conservatives agree that a number of their of his appointments and nominees are not actually competent for the roles that they serve.  And that's a bigger issue.  And that's something that even and I was not a fan of John McCain as as an elected official.  His Maverick thing, I think, was way blown out of proportion.  I'm just, you know, him being more decent than everyone else is not impressive to me.  All right, that's like saying...
He didn't shoot somebody on the floor, so he's a good guy.

Yeah, so I'm not in love with that framing of him, but... She could have said that.  So most people are not thinking about packing the courts.  They're thinking about being evicted.  They're thinking about surviving COVID or avoiding COVID or not being beat up by a police officer for doing nothing wrong.  They're thinking about a whole bunch of things.  They're not thinking about packing the courts.  That's a very small percentage of our population.  And for her to lead with that, it's a gotcha question.  that is problematic.  But you know what's also problematic?  The most important person in the Senate now is Joe Manchin.

Thank you.  He's like Mr.  Power Broker.  He and Kyrsten Sinema are going to be sitting there, you know, come and kiss my ring, come and move my vote.  How about we primary your asses?  Sorry.  Again, again, I should say.

It's arithmetic, right?  There's 50-50 tiebreaker is the vice president.  And if he says, I'm not going to vote this way, or I want this in exchange for my vote, then Biden is going to be in a tough position.  The problem, of course, is if Biden doesn't cower to Joe Manchin's bullying, um, potential bullying and he switches parties or he, or he becomes an independent and caucuses as has happened, you know, obviously that's something Bernie Sanders has done caucus with the Democrats and he caucuses with the Republicans.  Um, then, um, you know, Biden is not, I would hope that Biden does not reward him for that defection.  It'll make it hard for him to do things back home in West Virginia.  So he'll be a new darling of the right, but at a great cost.  So I don't know how this is going to bear out, but it's not going to be puppy dogs and rainbows until we can work out this political dynamic where you have these blue dogs and, I believe, traitors who are going to manipulate the Senate for their own personal

aggrandizement.  And we're going to have to treat them delicately.  I mean, that's the hardest part about this is I know progressives are going to be screaming, rightfully so, at the folks who keep pulling away, right?  From whether it's Joe Manchin, Kyrsten Sinema, or now Mark Kelly, who was just sworn in.  These are folks who've already shown that they're siding with big industries, whether it's oil and gas or the defense industry, Raytheon.  It's a concern because it's bad enough that we had a Republican Senate, but now we have to treat them with kid gloves so that they don't, you know, especially with Manchin, go and change parties.
